We are dedicated to preserving the integrity of open source security technologies and the communities that keep them thriving, and our team and our community includes world class security and nonprofit experts programmers and industry leaders dedicated to open source

Today's webinar will be about Suricata and DPDK, and hopefully everything you need to know to have Suricata running with DPDK, even though you don't know much about DPDK.
My name is Lucas Csismic, as Juliana mentioned, I'm the Suricata team member primarily and PhD student as well as research at Cessna.
Today, we will talk about general Suricata overview but I can assume you are probably already, you probably already heard about the Suricata.
So I'll rather introduce you to DPDK, and then we'll just go over some demo that I have prepared.
So, you would essentially, Suricata is a sensor that goes over traffic.
You've probably seen this image before, it's Suricata analyzes the traffic and produces some alerts based on some signatures.
Suricata can not only do that, but it can also monitor traffic, and also export full information, but also extract metadata and files of the traffic so that you have it available for later analysis.
Suricata can also record PCAPs, either triggered by rules, or you can have full packet capture.
With regards to signatures, it can do many different things, how it can detect the signatures within the traffic.

One of those can be, you can also detect different alerts in between flows, so you can have more clients communicating and if you see some weird traffic in between them, you can also raise an alert based on that.
It can also have datasets, and that essentially optimizes the way Suricata is used, but today's webinar will be about how Suricata receives traffic.
But before we'll go into that, I wanted to show you how Suricata actually processes the traffic, what's the architecture of Suricata.
So when you have a Suricata application, in that application you have multiple threads, and those threads are either management threads or packet processing threads.
Packet processing threads are called workers in Suricata, and to these threads, packets are delivered from the network interface.
Now what is happening within that packet processing thread?
Basically, everything that Suricata does, so when you have one packet processing thread, it contains multiple modules, and within those modules, different things are done.
The first module is the capture module, and an example of a capture module can be af-packet, af-ring, map-map, map-attack, and apdk.
So basically, capture module is how you receive traffic from the, let's say, outside world to your processing thread.
Then, when the packet is received in that capture module, then Suricata passes the packet to the decode module, where the packet is decoded into PON, IP address, UDP, TCP ports, and etc.
Then, when this packet is decoded, it goes through the detection phase, detection module, where it's matched against signatures with IP matching, content matching, and some other fields as well.

And when something is matched, or if, not even if, in network monitoring, it doesn't even require any rules, like the last stage of the processing is the output module, where basically, let's say the flow information is exported to these common output files,
or the result of the detection phase is exported to these common output files.
But this webinar is really about the capture module and dpdk, so how we receive the traffic.
Now, what is dpdk? It's Data Plane Development Kit.
It's basically, in a very brief term, it's a set of optimized open source libraries to speed up packet processing workloads.
It's an open source project governed by Linux Foundation.
Previously, it was governed by Intel, but then it was passed to Linux Foundation.
Now, contributors to dpdk are all over the world, although the main ones are, I think, Intel, NVIDIA, maybe Marvel, and some folks like that.
Now, if we compare capture modules, AF packet, NetMap, PeerFrame, dpdk, why is dpdk different?
I think there are two main points, and that is kernel bypass.
In dpdk, the packet doesn't go through the kernel, as we will see.
And the way dpdk receives packets from the NIC is by polling the NIC for new packets, whereas in other capture modules, it's provided by interrupts.
We will go over that as well.
And now, why should you consider using dpdk with Zerocata?
It's essentially, as I mentioned, it's focused on improving packet processing performance.
And it can add, let's say, up to 20%, but it really depends on the setup and the traffic, on the rules you use, the hardware you have.
So maybe in some cases, it might be even more than 20% of additional performance.
In IDS mode, we don't usually care much about the latency, but dpdk might have another positive effect on performance.
